Most people believe that developing countries are in a very bad situation: they have extreme poverty, are ruled by dictators, and seem to have no hope for change. But that is not true. A big transformation is happening. In the last 20 years, more than 700 million people have earned more money and left poverty. Also, six million fewer children die each year from disease, millions more girls are in school, and millions of people now have clean water.

Many managers try to make their feedback feel more positive by putting a negative comment between two positive ones. When this becomes a habit, employees may think the positive words are just a cover for the bad ones, so the good words lose their meaning. Instead, managers should give positive feedback to support and encourage good work, not just to soften the negative.

I am part of the Campaign to Stop Killer Robots. Don’t think about the scary robots you see in movies like the Terminator. Instead, think about what is happening today: the military is already using machines such as drones, automatic guns, and guard robots to kill people with very little human control. The next step could be robots that follow orders but choose on their own who to attack. I believe this would be very wrong and dangerous for people. We must be very careful about what we ask machines to do.

Overall, more people are learning English than all the other languages combined, and English is spoken in the most countries. But Chinese has the most native speakers. It seems that the number of native speakers does not determine how many people learn a language; instead, the number of learners is more linked to how many countries use that language.

Your manager stops you and says she needs to talk about your performance on the recent project. You worry all weekend, wondering what you might have done wrong. When you step into her office on Monday morning she starts by praising the good work you did, and you wonder if this is the usual praise that begins a feedback sandwich. You know the feedback sandwich: say something nice, give the real feedback, say something nice again.

Born in the USA is a fast, catchy rock album, but its lyrics still have real emotional weight. Behind the bright tunes are stories about the dark side of the American dream. Many songs focus on working people’s struggles and the anger they feel when life doesn’t bring riches or glory. For example, “Glory Days” is about small-town people looking back on their youth, when everything seemed possible, and “Downbound Train” tells of a young man whose life falls apart after he loses his job. It’s easy to think the artist draws on people he knew and the life he might have lived if he hadn’t become a star. The album clearly shows the Boss’s unique talent.

Lewis wants more of the world’s oceans to be protected. He would like the number of marine protected areas to increase from 3 per cent to 10 per cent. This is to help fix the damage caused by human activities like overfishing, pollution, and littering. During his trips to the ocean, Lewis has seen this damage with his own eyes. He has swum over coral reefs that have turned white because of rising water temperatures. He has also seen lifeless areas under the shallow waters of the Red Sea, full of plastic and no signs of life. Pugh believes that nature can heal if we give it a chance. But time is running out. If we do not start taking care of our seas, we may face a problem that is too big to solve.

Terrie Sharp is a best-selling author who knows how to tell a great story. She has won the Olive Crime Writer Award twice. She grew up on a housing estate in Glasgow that had the highest crime rate, where she learned to keep quiet, stay out of trouble, and even how to open a car door with a knife. Luckily, she used this knowledge only to write her novels. Today, she often appears on popular daytime shows such as Police Today and speaks at writing conferences across the UK.

Are things getting worse every day? Is progress impossible?  
In *Enlightenment Now*, Steven Pinker looks at the big picture of human progress and finds good news.  
We are living longer, healthier, freer, and happier lives.  
Pinker says the real problem is that the Enlightenment values of reason and science are being attacked.  
When commentators and demagogues appeal to people’s tribal feelings, fatalism, and distrust, we risk serious damage to important institutions like democracy and global cooperation.

In older horror movies, when the main characters were in trouble, they couldn't call for help or the police. Now, mobile phones make that harder to believe. How do filmmakers keep the tension? They use no phone coverage. If you're the hero in a horror movie, it's likely that when you really need to call for help, your phone will have no signal. Or your battery might die just as you're trying to call. Or both can happen.

In the 1950s, banana farmers in Central America were losing their best crop, the Gros Michel banana, also called Big Mike. Now the same problem is happening to its replacement, the Cavendish banana. The Gros Michel was popular because it was easy to ship, had a thick skin, and tasted sweet. It grew well in Central American plantations. United Fruit, the biggest grower and exporter in South America at that time, produced the bananas in the most efficient way. They took shoots from the stems of existing plants instead of growing new ones from seeds, and planted them close together in large fields.

Most spiders make venom, but they use it to catch bugs, not to hurt people. Only about 25 kinds of spiders have venom that is truly dangerous to humans. A bite from one of these spiders can hurt, yet it almost never kills anyone. For example, Australia’s Sydney funnel-web spider has not caused any deaths since doctors created a special medicine called antivenom in 1981. Hairy spiders, such as tarantulas, have another trick. When they feel scared, they can shoot tiny, itchy hairs into the air. These hairs can stick in an enemy’s skin or eyes and cause a sharp, burning feeling.

This horror movie pattern was very common in late-20th-century films. It begins with a group of teenagers having fun, and ends with everyone dead except one girl. At first, the girl is innocent, shy, and not very strong. By the end, she becomes tough and very resourceful. The last girl almost always survives.

If we want to know where our ability for advanced speech comes from, we need to study how our brains differ from those of other species. It is not only about the size of the brain; we must also consider what other abilities the brain has and when and why those abilities changed. There are very few physical clues. Artifacts left by our ancestors do not show what speech they could produce. However, we can see changes in the mouth, throat, and tongue in early human remains. By about 100,000 years ago, humans had developed the ability to make complex sounds. Before that, scientists who study evolution can only guess whether early humans used simple sounds.

Society, not nature, tells us that girls should prefer arts and humanities and leave maths and physics to boys. There is also a lack of positive female role models in science-related jobs for young people to see. Cartoons and stories often show the crazy scientist, genius inventor, or adventurous astronaut as a man. People often think scientists are geeky, have poor social skills, or that their work is lonely and detached from the rest of the world. These media stereotypes are false, but they can make girls feel they do not identify with scientists and see science as an unappealing career. Seeing more positive female role models in science would give girls more confidence and a stronger sense of belonging in those subjects.

The Scallion is a weekly newspaper distributed for free in faculty buildings, reaching around 10,000 students. Students write and produce the entire newspaper. A survey found that students and staff value it for entertainment, culture, and work experience. However, printing costs are high. Also, some students cannot easily get the paper because it is only available on campus. Many copies end up as litter, which causes environmental concerns.

At Girox Foods, our yearly staff turnover is about 12 per cent. While this may not appear high, the industry average is seven per cent. The main goal of this report is to look into why employees feel engaged here and, from that, give suggestions to make the workplace better and keep more people on the team.

Much of what the speaker said felt true. I think there's a risk that the more connected we are, the more isolated we feel. I don't see this as a big issue for my generation, which lived without technology for a long time. We know how to be alone and, more importantly, we know it's OK to be alone. But people under 20 are different. They're so busy communicating that they rarely feel real solitude, and they may not learn how to enjoy their own company. They're also learning to talk through messages they can edit, instead of learning how to have a real conversation, in real time, with the person in front of them.

Don’t always follow positive feedback with negative feedback. If positive and negative feedback always go together, the positive feedback can lose value and be ignored. Make sure you sometimes give positive feedback on its own, and avoid the urge to add constructive criticism.
